instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot issue
threads.message:
This arrived with liquid damage on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. Replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and surrounding components. Goes to 20v 0.13a now. 

<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is 0v with an odd type of short. If the board is not powered on for a few minutes diode mode is .335  After power is applied and after checking about a minute later a short of 0.38 appears. 

Removed all power filter caps and replaced <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> but no change.

Anything else worth trying or is it a bad nand?

DFU mode fails with error 4025  "give up waiting for device to transition"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot issue
threads.message:
I suppose you've meant 0.038; as 0.38 is higher than 0.335.
This behavior may be caused by remanent voltage; even if you do not detect 2V5 there.
Can you catch another SSD voltage?
The G3S voltages come on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot issue
threads.message:
I'm not sure if these DFU errors have any sense for Apple technicians even.
Pretty sure they will never release an explanation for such errors.

If basic voltages are present, not sure if something else than NAND and T2 can impede DFU completion.
Several times I saw that SSD voltages come on after DFU revive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boot issue
threads.message:
Must be a bad T2 then since that's the only thing that heats up on thermal cam.

Noticed a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V0_MESA</SIGNAL>. Replaced <CHIP>U4910</CHIP>. Short is gone. 3.3v appears on FL4910 but 0v on <CAPACITOR>C4916</CAPACITOR>
